texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The  Linux Vendor Firmware Service  (LVFS) and  fwupd  turned the troublesome and time consuming activities of updating all kinds of firmware for laptops, desktops, and servers into something much easier. Check your list of updated firmware, update it, and submit feedback for the vendors when something doesn't work. You can even get notifications right inside GUI applications, such as GNOME Software, that notify you about updates and allow you to install them with one click.
texts.text: The  Linux Vendor Firmware Service  (LVFS) and  fwupd  turned the troublesome and time consuming activities of updating all kinds of firmware for laptops, desktops, and servers into something much easier. Check your list of updated firmware, update it, and submit feedback for the vendors when something doesn't work. You can even get notifications right inside GUI applications, such as GNOME Software, that notify you about updates and allow you to install them with one click.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, not all vendors participate in LVFS and some vendors only participate in LVFS for some devices. I've had a  small Supermicro server  at home that's been offline for quite some time. I decided to get it back online for some new projects and I discovered that the BIOS and BMC firmware were both extremely old.
texts.text: However, not all vendors participate in LVFS and some vendors only participate in LVFS for some devices. I've had a  small Supermicro server  at home that's been offline for quite some time. I decided to get it back online for some new projects and I discovered that the BIOS and BMC firmware were both extremely old.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This device isn't included in LVFS, so we're stuck with older methods.
texts.text: This device isn't included in LVFS, so we're stuck with older methods.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The  baseband management controller , or BMC, is an always-running component that provides out-of-band access to my server. I can control the server's power, view a virtrual console, or control certain BIOS configurations from a web browser or IPMI client.
texts.text: The  baseband management controller , or BMC, is an always-running component that provides out-of-band access to my server. I can control the server's power, view a virtrual console, or control certain BIOS configurations from a web browser or IPMI client.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, Supermicro makes it easy to update the BMC directly from the web interface. Our first step is to identify which board is inside the machine:
texts.text: Luckily, Supermicro makes it easy to update the BMC directly from the web interface. Our first step is to identify which board is inside the machine:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ sudo dmidecode -t 2
# dmidecode 3.3
Getting SMBIOS data from sysfs.
SMBIOS 2.8 present.

Handle 0x0002, DMI type 2, 15 bytes
Base Board Information
	Manufacturer: Supermicro
	Product Name: X10SDV-TLN4F
	Version: 1.02
	Serial Number: xxxxxxxxxxxx
	Asset Tag: To be filled by O.E.M.
	Features:
		Board is a hosting board
		Board is replaceable
	Location In Chassis: To be filled by O.E.M.
	Chassis Handle: 0x0003
	Type: Motherboard
	Contained Object Handles: 0
texts.text:
$ sudo dmidecode -t 2
# dmidecode 3.3
Getting SMBIOS data from sysfs.
SMBIOS 2.8 present.

Handle 0x0002, DMI type 2, 15 bytes
Base Board Information
	Manufacturer: Supermicro
	Product Name: X10SDV-TLN4F
	Version: 1.02
	Serial Number: xxxxxxxxxxxx
	Asset Tag: To be filled by O.E.M.
	Features:
		Board is a hosting board
		Board is replaceable
	Location In Chassis: To be filled by O.E.M.
	Chassis Handle: 0x0003
	Type: Motherboard
	Contained Object Handles: 0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: for type 2 DMI data should give you the motherboard model in the
texts.text: for type 2 DMI data should give you the motherboard model in the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: field. In this case, mine is
texts.text: field. In this case, mine is

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . I ran over to  Supermicro's BMC List , typed in the motherboard model number, and downloaded the zip file. After unpacking the zip, I had a bunch of items:
texts.text: . I ran over to  Supermicro's BMC List , typed in the motherboard model number, and downloaded the zip file. After unpacking the zip, I had a bunch of items:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: contains the firmware update for the BMC. Now access your IPMI interface via a web browser and authenticate. Follow these steps:
texts.text: contains the firmware update for the BMC. Now access your IPMI interface via a web browser and authenticate. Follow these steps:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The upload process took around a minute and the BMC update took four or five minutes. The BMC will respond to pings early after the update but it will take a while for the web interface to respond. Be patient!
texts.text: The upload process took around a minute and the BMC update took four or five minutes. The BMC will respond to pings early after the update but it will take a while for the web interface to respond. Be patient!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you have the appropriate license for your BMC, you can update the BIOS right from the BMC interface. I don't have that license. Let's find another way!
texts.text: If you have the appropriate license for your BMC, you can update the BIOS right from the BMC interface. I don't have that license. Let's find another way!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by downloading Supermicro's  SUM utility . The software is available after the registration step (which is free). In my case, I needed the second download (not the UEFI one) since my server is a little older.
texts.text: Start by downloading Supermicro's  SUM utility . The software is available after the registration step (which is free). In my case, I needed the second download (not the UEFI one) since my server is a little older.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we need to download the BIOS firmware itself. One of the easiest methods I've seen for this is to throw
texts.text: Now we need to download the BIOS firmware itself. One of the easiest methods I've seen for this is to throw

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (replace with your motherboard model) into Google and click the result. Then look for a  Update your BIOS  link under Links & Resources  on the right side. That takes you directly to a zip file to download.
texts.text: (replace with your motherboard model) into Google and click the result. Then look for a  Update your BIOS  link under Links & Resources  on the right side. That takes you directly to a zip file to download.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ) and move the SUM zip as well as your firmware zip file in that directory. Some of these zip files have no directory prefix included and they will clobber your working directory. 🤦🏻‍♂️
texts.text: ) and move the SUM zip as well as your firmware zip file in that directory. Some of these zip files have no directory prefix included and they will clobber your working directory. 🤦🏻‍♂️

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Unpack both zip files and find the
texts.text: Unpack both zip files and find the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Great! Now we need to find the BIOS firmware file. In most cases, they start with a few characters from your motherboard and end in a numerical extension:
texts.text: Great! Now we need to find the BIOS firmware file. In most cases, they start with a few characters from your motherboard and end in a numerical extension:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ ls -1
AFUDOSU.smc
BIOS_X10SDV-TLNF_20210604_2.3_STDsp.zip
CHOICE.SMC
FDT.smc
FLASH.BAT
'Readme for AMI BIOS.txt'
sum_2.8.0_Linux_x86_64
sum_2.8.0_Linux_x86_64_20220126.tar.gz
X10SDVF1.604
texts.text:
$ ls -1
AFUDOSU.smc
BIOS_X10SDV-TLNF_20210604_2.3_STDsp.zip
CHOICE.SMC
FDT.smc
FLASH.BAT
'Readme for AMI BIOS.txt'
sum_2.8.0_Linux_x86_64
sum_2.8.0_Linux_x86_64_20220126.tar.gz
X10SDVF1.604

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  UPGRADING BIOS FIRMWARE IS SERIOUS BUSINESS.  😱 If an upgrade goes wrong, it may be challenging to get the system running properly again. I've recovered from some pretty awful BIOS update failures in the past on most x86 systems, but it was rarely an enjoyable process. Be sure you have  stable power for the device , you are running the update  inside tmux  (especially if connected via ssh), and you  have time  to complete the operation.
texts.text: 💣  UPGRADING BIOS FIRMWARE IS SERIOUS BUSINESS.  😱 If an upgrade goes wrong, it may be challenging to get the system running properly again. I've recovered from some pretty awful BIOS update failures in the past on most x86 systems, but it was rarely an enjoyable process. Be sure you have  stable power for the device , you are running the update  inside tmux  (especially if connected via ssh), and you  have time  to complete the operation.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: session, always. Seriously. Don't skip this step.
texts.text: session, always. Seriously. Don't skip this step.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: session  (which I'm sure you started because you were paying attention) , let's update the firmware:
texts.text: session  (which I'm sure you started because you were paying attention) , let's update the firmware:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ sudo ./sum -c UpdateBios --file /home/major/bios/X10SDVF1.604
Supermicro Update Manager (for UEFI BIOS) 2.8.0 (2022/01/26) (x86_64)
Copyright(C) 2013-2022 Super Micro Computer, Inc. All rights reserved.

WARNING: BIOS setting will be reset without option --preserve_setting
Reading BIOS flash ..................... (100%)
Writing BIOS flash ..................... (100%)
Verifying BIOS flash ................... (100%)
Checking ME Firmware ...
Putting ME data to BIOS ................ (100%)
Writing ME region in BIOS flash ...
 - FDT won't be updated when ME is not in Manufacturing mode!!
   BIOS upgrade continues...
 - Updated Recovery Loader to OPRx
 - Updated FPT, MFSB, FTPR and MFS
 - ME Entire Image done
WARNING:Must power cycle or restart the system for the changes to take effect!
texts.text:
$ sudo ./sum -c UpdateBios --file /home/major/bios/X10SDVF1.604
Supermicro Update Manager (for UEFI BIOS) 2.8.0 (2022/01/26) (x86_64)
Copyright(C) 2013-2022 Super Micro Computer, Inc. All rights reserved.

WARNING: BIOS setting will be reset without option --preserve_setting
Reading BIOS flash ..................... (100%)
Writing BIOS flash ..................... (100%)
Verifying BIOS flash ................... (100%)
Checking ME Firmware ...
Putting ME data to BIOS ................ (100%)
Writing ME region in BIOS flash ...
 - FDT won't be updated when ME is not in Manufacturing mode!!
   BIOS upgrade continues...
 - Updated Recovery Loader to OPRx
 - Updated FPT, MFSB, FTPR and MFS
 - ME Entire Image done
WARNING:Must power cycle or restart the system for the changes to take effect!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Awesome! My preference here is to power down, wait a few seconds, and power it back up. I've had issues in the past with soft restarts after BIOS upgrades on non-laptop systems and I'm ultra cautious.
texts.text: Awesome! My preference here is to power down, wait a few seconds, and power it back up. I've had issues in the past with soft restarts after BIOS upgrades on non-laptop systems and I'm ultra cautious.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once it's fully powered down, power it back up using the BMC/IPMI or via the button on the device. If all goes well, you should see a new firmware version after boot:
texts.text: Once it's fully powered down, power it back up using the BMC/IPMI or via the button on the device. If all goes well, you should see a new firmware version after boot:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ sudo dmidecode -t 0
# dmidecode 3.3
Getting SMBIOS data from sysfs.
SMBIOS 2.8 present.

Handle 0x0000, DMI type 0, 24 bytes
BIOS Information
	Vendor: American Megatrends Inc.
	Version: 2.3
	Release Date: 06/04/2021
	Address: 0xF0000
	Runtime Size: 64 kB
	ROM Size: 16 MB
texts.text:
$ sudo dmidecode -t 0
# dmidecode 3.3
Getting SMBIOS data from sysfs.
SMBIOS 2.8 present.

Handle 0x0000, DMI type 0, 24 bytes
BIOS Information
	Vendor: American Megatrends Inc.
	Version: 2.3
	Release Date: 06/04/2021
	Address: 0xF0000
	Runtime Size: 64 kB
	ROM Size: 16 MB

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Perfect! 🎉 I downloaded version 2.3 from Supermicro's site and it's now running on my server!
texts.text: Perfect! 🎉 I downloaded version 2.3 from Supermicro's site and it's now running on my server!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You may want to do some additional (optional) steps depending on your configuration.
texts.text: You may want to do some additional (optional) steps depending on your configuration.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I rebooted into the BIOS and chose to load the optimized defaults in case something important was changed in the latest BIOS firmware. This may revert a few of your settings if you had some customizations, so be sure to roll through the BIOS menu and look for any of those issues.
texts.text: I rebooted into the BIOS and chose to load the optimized defaults in case something important was changed in the latest BIOS firmware. This may revert a few of your settings if you had some customizations, so be sure to roll through the BIOS menu and look for any of those issues.
